# News comment title:
Is Climate Change to Blame for the Oklahoma Tornado?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Yes, artificially altering the ecology is directly responsible.  That is nature's ecology fighting back with a vengeance at being forced to die by, and caused directly by too many of her DNA evolutionary by-products known as homo sapien sapiens.  Humans are supposed to have more advanced cerebral skills.  Killing off the ecology is blatant physical evidence too many human brains haven't left the most primitive of cerebral stages of evolutionary development remaining at mine, mine, and only mine.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Yes, artificially altering the ecology is directly responsible.  That is nature's ecology fighting back with a vengeance at being forced to die by, and caused directly by too many of her DNA evolutionary by-products known as homo sapien sapiens.  Humans are supposed to have more advanced cerebral skills.  Killing off the ecology is blatant physical evidence too many human brains haven't left the most primitive of cerebral stages of evolutionary development remaining at mine, mine, and only mine.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


 Anthropogenic climate disruption affects every square inch of the globe. That would also include tornado alley.  How the two may interface remains to be seen, and since this is an accelerating problem nothing you know today or tomorrow will be the last word.  If you want to gamble on Capital providing for your grandchildren if the three percent of scientists they have on the payroll turn out to be wrong, I'd say you're expecting a little more than you'll get 

Why entrust non expert corporate entities who exist only to realize profit and have no apparatus in place to tell right from wrong with the future of your offspring?  If you're wrong, and there's a better than 97% chance you are, you've traded their freedom for that of your children and grandchildren. 

Greed certainly does cloud men's minds,  but in some of them, those clouds  have condensed to granite. 

The problem with greed is it exists in the perpetual moment. It has no sense of past nor portent of the future. It simply exists and feeds.  That's not a paradigm for responsible, prudent goverment. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
WATCH: What Does 400 ppm Mean? Talking with Climate Scientist Michael Mann

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
In all walks of personal life it is wise to establish priorities. In world government's, policy makers and politicians, it is imperative that they establish priorities. Government leaders are supposed to first protect the citizens which they rule, whether elected or otherwise. 

With global warming now firmly in hand with an atmospheric CO2 level of 400 ppm and rapidly rising, priority's must be established and the number ONE priority related to global warming must be the issue which will at some time in the near future destroy all life on Earth... The Arctic's "Ticking Time Bomb".

The Arctic region of Earth is warming much faster than any other location on the planet, second is Antarctica.  As the Arctic continues to heat up the Arctic Ocean sea ice is rapidly disappearing and in the shallow ocean's sub sea floor are trillions of tons of methane gas safely locked in frozen permafrost. 

As the shallow Arctic Ocean becomes ice free the permafrost melts and when ice or permafrost melts, ANYTHING locked in the ice or permafrost is freed and if it's a gas, such as methane gas, CH4, it then enters the atmosphere. 

Scientists have learned that methane gas is 105 times more potent than is CO2 when it first enters the atmosphere and is still 25 times as potent after it has been in the atmosphere for 100 years.....  Therefore; if and when only a trillion tons of methane gas enters the atmosphere from the Arctic's melting permafrost, it would be equal to (*105 trillion tons*) of  CO2 added to the atmospheric greenhouse gas mixture.... In 2012 scientists were concerned when human activity emitted 44 billion tons of CO2 into the atmosphere.  44 billion is a pittance when compare to 105 trillion .  

The result of that happening will be as deadly serious as an incoming asteroid the size of Rhode Island hitting our atmosphere.  In other words, it would eradicate almost all life on Earth, leaving bacterial life and perhaps some deep sea life.  

Now at the current rate of Arctic sea ice and permafrost melt, that disaster could happen at any time now, two years, three, five or ten...  No one can predict the exact time we have remaining, but we certainly can predict that it will happen if we humans, world governments, who have the power and the finances, do nothing about it and allow it to happen. 

The number one priority must be to address the Arctic methane issue and indeed there are many other top priorities such as ocean acidification, severe global climate changes, but when establishing priority's there has to be a number ONE.  There has to be a number one if people in command aren't ignorant of the issue or are stupid.

  http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10773020

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Another priority might be to get denialists to understand that explaining only one half of a feedback cycle is similar to not explaining it all, and that this is actually misinformation. Another priority might be to get denialists to stop constructing strawmen.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Dude, all I did was ask you for a link. Was that so impossible? What authority are you citing that there's a multiple contintental model for 'snowball earth' formation.  

It looks like just your own.  Oh, well...

If men could be made better—or even only happier—by teaching them that two and two make five there would be plenty of fools to advocate that method, but it would remain anti-social none the less. If the theologians could only agree on their doctrines their unanimity might have some evidential value, just as the agreement of all politicians that the first duty of the citizen is to obey them and admire them has some evidential value. H L Mencken
